title: 110_s2006
content: The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for privately-owned or investor-owned power facilities that provide electric or natural gas service to retail customers under State or local jurisdiction, including leased facilities. Conditions for contributions under the Act are also amended. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for privately-owned or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of the facility and associated expenses. Conditions for assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities are outlined in the Act. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" allows for assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster, with conditions outlined for such assistance. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" allows contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster, with specific conditions for eligibility based on the costs of repair, restoration, or replacement exceeding certain thresholds. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" allows private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster to apply for funds if their expenses exceed $500,000,000 and if 25% or more of the population in the area had taxable income below the Federal poverty level. Private or investor-owned power facilities meeting specific requirements can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of a major disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. Federal assistance is limited under this section for disaster relief. Federal assistance for disaster relief to private or investor-owned power facilities is limited to eligible costs exceeding $10,000,000. Costs from previous major disasters within a 12-month period will be aggregated for determination. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications within 30 days. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for federal assistance. Assistance applications must be approved or disapproved within 30 days by the President. Private or investor-owned power facilities may receive a contribution equal to 75 percent of the Federal estimate for repairing, restoring, or replacing the facility. The funds can be used to repair, restore, or expand other power facilities owned by the person. Private or investor-owned power facilities can receive funding for repair, restoration, expansion, or construction of new facilities after a major disaster. The eligible costs now include private or investor-owned power facilities in addition to public and nonprofit facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with Section 3 taking effect immediately.
